newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Israeli shares close lower in thin trading.
newsitem.headline: Israeli shares close lower in thin trading.

text.p: Israeli shares closed lower on Thursday for the third consecutive session on low volume as political uncertainty and the sharp decline of the shekel depressed prices, traders said.
The benchmark Mishtanim index of the top 100 shares ended down 0.87 percent, or 2.52 points, to 285.50 on low all-share turnover of 150 million shekels against 170 million shekels on Wednesday.
The Maof 25 blue chip index closed 0.90 percent lower at 293.02.

"There is much political and economic uncertainty and this is bad for the market. The latest events indicate that the government may not last much longer," said Arik Rotstein of Bloch Rotstein Securities and Investments. "The rapid decline of the shekel is only adding to investor uncertainty."
Israeli President Ezer Weizman urged Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's cabinet on Thursday to stop squabbling and get back to work on Middle East peace-making.

Two ministers have quit in anger. Others have refused to speak to Netanyahu and boycotted cabinet meetings while several coalition members abandoned him in a parliamentary no-confidence vote this week.

The shekel has fallen sharply since last Friday, shortly after the government announced a reform of the exchange rate regime and the Bank of Israel lowered the base rate by a steep 1.2 percentage points to 12.7 percent.
But Rotstein said a sharp decline of the shekel might lead to higher inflation and even to a decision of the Bank of Israel to raise its key lending rate.
"If the devaluation of the shekel continues this will have an immediate impact on the results of companies that took foreign currency loans," Rotstein said.

Danni Scharia of Capital Securities said the Bank of Israel must intervene in the forex market. "If he doesn't stop the shekel's fall it could snowball," he said. "It will also worsen the condition of many companies, which are about the publish their results."
Rotstein said the recent decline of the market could also be seen as a technical correction.
"The fact that activity is also falling supports the feeling that this is only a correction. I believe that the Mishtanim will stop at around 270 points and the Maof at 280," he said.

Scharia agreed and is more optimistic about the Maof's floor. "The slide will stop once the Maof reaches 290 points. We haven't seen such low activity for a long time and that's a clear indicator that it's only a correction," he said.

The most active shares were Koor Industries, which fell 2.0 percent to 32,064 agorot on volume of 12 million shekels; Teva Pharmaceutical Industries, which gained 2.5 percent to 22,864 agorot on turnover of 10.9 million shekels; and Bank Leumi, which lost 2.0 percent at 552 agorot on turnover of 9.3 million shekels.
- Dan Gerstenfeld, Tel Aviv newsroom, 972-3-537-2211 x233
